div.p: THE OCEAN SPECTRE, AN ENTIRE NEW GRAND MELO DRAME: IN FIVE ACTS. Intersperced with Songs, Chorusses, &c.
div.l: "The critic's eye, that microscope of wit,
"Sees hairs, and pores, examined bit by bit;
"In Poets, as true genius is but rare,
"True taste as seldom is the Critic's share;
"Both must alike from heaven derive their light,
"Those born to judge, as well as those to write."
div.p: TRANSLATED FROM THE FRENCH OF LE SPECTRE DE L'OCEAN. WRITTEN BY FLAREAU.
Copy right secured according to law.

div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.

list.item: LORENZO—Son of Flavio, in love with Isabella.
DON PEDRAS—Captain of Banditti, in l • ve w • Florinda.

div.head: TYPOGRAPHICAL ERRORS
div.p: For leniament, read lineament—exquesite, ex • site—moment, moments—imovable, immoveable— • fections, affection—witi • in, within.

div.head: THE OCEAN SPECTRE.
ACT I.
SCENE I.—VENICE.—A Grotesque garden▪
div.p: TIS morn—bright Phoebus from his aether throne refulgent smiles; his magic light the earth illumines, drives sable night from view, and shews all nature rich by his magnificence. Each dreary waste and dampen'd lowly ground, reeking thro' heat, the sun exhaling dews to heaven's high summit. His orient reflecting beams ineffably rich, surpasses human comprehension!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Ah my dear friend Harr • ; melancholy!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Your absence was the cause, where have • ou been? where past you the night away?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: At the feast of Venus and Cupid.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Explain.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
When we parted last night by accident, I • ravers'd streets, lanes, crooked and strait to find • ou, but in vain my search; the night being dark, I • t my way; heavy clouds were rising with great • elocity, and the hour being very late I despaired of •• nding my lodgings—the warring elements thun
• er'd o'er my head! the rain in torrents fell—the
winds blew, as tho' boreas would have spent himself in a single blast—but oh, in the end what a lucky dog was I!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Your luck, if by your wardrobe I may judge, hath been in the swimming line.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: True Harry, true. Ha, ha. ha.
Thou'rt in good spirits faith.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
I spy'd a head by the lightnings flash, a monastery decay'd, and old, at which I soon arriv'd; under that convent I stow'd my half drown'd body, I had not long been there, e'er I observed a black fellow with a lanthorn in his hand, making toward me; the rain slackened, and I left the place to me • him, in hopes to gain from him information, that might find my home. He put his fingers to his mout • and whisteled very loud, I waited for a while, and he made a second noise still louder than the former— none answered him, and being curious, thinking 〈◊〉 a signal, made bold myself to answer it, being hood • ed with my cloak, I came up to him, waiting th • event; he told me "his mistress was waiting im • patiently for my presence in her bed chamber, havin • but now hurried her gouty husband to bed." started at this so unexpected an event, knowing n • what to do—he perceiving not his mistake, resolve me upon the intrigue. I followed him first crou •
ing a purse into his hand—he led me thro' an arch • gallery, and several windings till I felt almost lost the superb mansion; at length he opened a glass foldi •• door, when an angel (for so I must call her,) appear before me—a sattin night gown was all that veil • her heavenly form, the wanton tresses careless han •• ing on her alabaster neck, pictured to me Venus h •• self; oh Harry, Harry, my throbbing bosom most burst—I was then in Elysium, transported ••• yond myself 'twixt love and hope! recovering mys •••
a little, the precious moment I improved, and extinguish'd the waxen taper; at which she express'd surprise: I apologized in a quite low whisper and clasped her in my arms—Harry guess you the rest, for more I'll not tell thee about tha • .

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: When will you leave off your rakish pranks?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: When tongues forget to tell us love sick ditty's—when eyes forget to blandish languishing rays upon the heart—In short when women think no more of men, I'll hate them all, but not I'm sure till then.

sp.speaker: Hen,
sp.p: Have you any thing more to expect from your fair dulcinea?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Nothing more from her I fear: but my rival! I have something to expect from him, I'll tell you the sequel—while I lay in amorous pastime, with this Venus, encircling, in pops a stranger, not knowing who could thus intrude, I requested of the lady • o chide him; who, when she beheld shrieked aloud! he was the very person she thought then in her arms. I sprung from my downy repast, and bolted the door, which had been neglected; by my rival's assistance the lady had partly recovered her scattered senses. The husband had thrice thundered at the portal to know the c • use of the alarm. She entreated of us both to make our escape, for fear we should be discovered, and put one way there was left for flight.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: That was, taking a cold bath by a dangerous leap from the back window.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: And did you so,

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: No option was left me—I sprang in the water from the window, my rival followed—judge • he transition, from a warm bath to a cold one.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Did you learn the name of your rival?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
His name is Signior Lorenzo. When we
reached the shore, he demanded satisfaction; I told him I knew of now insult offered, I thought therefore no satisfaction requisite; but that I would every day run the same risk, to be rewarded thus at night.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Then you have promised to fight him?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: This morning at six o'clock.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: 'Tis a barbarous custom.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: What serious again?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: That honor sanctions, but morality more wise, more just, condemns. What a mistaken sense of honor; what votary's of vice. What toil, what peril do parents undergo for their progeny? Is this filial reverencial gratitude? the pride of the fond doating sire, and matrons tender care; a mind of many years cultivation; is matured to benefit society; for one rash step falls a voluntary sacr • fice, and leaves to endless inconsolable misery the fountain of his existence.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Think you Harry I am wrong? I am indeed sorry if you do, but I know you are my friend, and would not willingly do me wrong. Think you I would unnecessarily plunge myself in danger, or a living creature on earth? when impetuous, foolish men for a trivial amour, will set a fellow creatures life in an awful b • llance, which reclining either way, may prove fatal to one or both, think you the omnipotent would prosper a wretch so baneful? Oh no indignant fate would pronounce sentence aloud, and hurl the unnatural aggressor to perdition.

sp.speaker: Hen,
sp.p: That is weighty reasoning.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
Could I with honour decline the combat, I would willingly indeed—but to be branded with a coward's name, I would not disgrace my country so. No American yet has disgraced our annals by inglorious cowardice; nor shall it be said, that one o •
Columbia's sons, though in a foreign land, did e'er forget the glorious inheritance of his ancestors.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: It cannot be avoided always I confess, I will be your second.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Thank you my dear fellow, thanks; my conduct I cannot impeach as criminal, I have only stolen that from him, that would have been stolen by another. Come Harry we'll prepare and away; and as our cause is just so may it prosper. (Exeunt.)

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter LORENZO and DON PEDRAS in deep consultation.

sp.speaker: Ped.
Lor.
sp.p: (feigning a smile of indignation upon Pedras, as a cloak for his acceptance.) If thou'rt a man, that did not come from thy heart.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (confused.) Signio • ! friendship alone, and the preservation of thy life, (which to me is more precious than my own,) urg'd thus far my proffer'd kindness.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Friendship however great, when it promotes dishonour as a proof, debases manhood.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Indeed thou wrong'st me, and for my friendship 'tis hard to be thus us'd,

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Forgive me Pedias, but thy advice I cannot take.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Act as thy will directs—here comes one whose martial front alone would strike the chickens dead—be prevailed upon Signior, he's coming quick upon us—should he procure the number requisite—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: (hesitating.) Well, well I consent. (retires up the ground.)

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: A friend to every villain—I hope you are the same, then you will be a friend to me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: By heaven 'tis one of my own band. (aside. Fearful of being exposed, comes up to the Ruffian and speaks to him in a low tone.) Hush!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Why Captain!—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Push on your life, seem not to know me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: [comes down.] Art thou a deep read villain?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: As for reading I never knew much about it, I could write pothooks and trammels once. But if you mean a fellow that does not fear the Devil, inquisition, nor gog magog; if you mean one that never told the truth though it suited him best, if you mean one that can stop a man's whistling pipes in a twinkling; 'though I don't like to praise myself, I'm the very chap for your money.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Could'st thou procure me a dozen?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: No • that I can recommend • o strong as myself— I know indeed many that pretend to rob, murder, ravish, and such petty tricks, but even in that, they are ungentlemanlike bunglers, demme—but for myself I have always had the credit of doing any thing in that genteel way, with the best grace of any other gentleman in all these parts. Why a night or two ago I made enough money to keep me a month in idleness.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: A mere trifle as a body may say, killing a bastard child, that's all.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Killing a child?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p:
Yes, as good luck would have it, my cellebrity that way being suspected, I was sent for to do the job, the little nobody's child did squeak a ••
squall most damnably—fearful the little fellow might catch cold, I put my hat on his head, and my cloak round him. What is to be done with this little fellow? says I—you must kill him says he, crouding a weighty purse into my hand—'tis done says I, putting it into my pocket. I left him—pop't off in a boat, hung an ornament round his neck, down he went to the bottom safe enough, and never said a word. A hundred such jobs a week, would keep me in style in a short time without any such labour.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Did't thou never know fear?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Bless you Sir, very often; I am always afraid a man will never pay, that does not pay beforehand, for such trifles are always cash jobs. (pulls off his hat, and holds out his hand.)

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Take thou that, 'twill silence all thy scruples of conscience effectually. (gives a purse.)

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: [puts it in his pocket, puts on his hat and makes a low bow.] I am your slave. How many men, women▪ children, orphans, babes, old maids, and bastards must I kill for this?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Bring with thee a dozen of the most daring villains thou knowest, and meet me here immediately,

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: When I find a person that is generous and tender hearted like myself, my conscience pricks me if I do not do him justice, and be punctual to my word and honour. [exit Ruf.]

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Noble Signior, what think'st thou now?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O What a wretch is that! he seem'd so sunk in villainy already the goading stings of concience cannot reach him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You seem mov'd Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Then I seem not more than what I really do feel.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Will't thou not tell thy faithful Pedras of the cause?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: That would avail but little towards removing the weight upon my soul. Murdering innocence! O lovely innocence!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why harp you upon those words? sure thou'rt not guilty.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: D • d'st thou never before observe?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oft have I m • rk'd thy tardy steps, thy downcast eye, with folded arms, and head reclining to the ear • h, and ever and ano • , a heavy sigh stole from thy bosom, as if in that sigh you breath'd your life away.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Alas! my heart and bosom have long been strangers!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And stranger yet it appears to me that I have not been entrusted with the cause.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My heart's entom'd in the bowels of the watry gulph, 'twill never reign within my breast again!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Then do not rob me of my share of grief; let me partake of thine.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
I scruple not thy fidelity now, I think I may in safety breathe to thee, the miseries with which my bosom's fraught. Six years have elaps'd since in the dead o •• ig • t, when on the seas all was tranquil as heaven's list'ning cherubims; I was in possession of my love; my heart then was pure, then was unpolluted; never since that cars'd night have I known rest; absorb'd in sorrow I have ever been, bu • death alone can ease me of my pain; when on the vessel's d • ck myself and Flo • ella stood, exchanging vows of constancy and love; when all below was hush'd, at the midnight hour; h • r accents • o melodious dropt, she the air pregnated with such salubrious breath, ambrosial sweets engender'd on her lips! Oh! with what transport I press'd my lips to her's; possess'd
• t once of all my hearts desire, created passions in • e that grew mad! passions which never before I • elt so stubborn, engrossed with violence my trembling • ame; my panting breast grew wild, and like a • antic man I clasp'd her in my arms, resolved to enjoy • y force those charms, which if patience had taken • e rein, but for a little while would have voluntarily • ielded to me!—sudden she sprang from my embrace, •• d threw her body in the foaming surge! Oh! then • hat horror child my faultering soul! she sunk! she • rowned! and with her all my happiness forever!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Grieve not for the loss of her—the beautiou •
•• abella—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Sister to the unfortunate Florella.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Good heaven! thine own cousin?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Too true indeed—my hopes are blasted there; • uld I obtain her, methought 'twould in part remove • y melancholly. My last visit to Padua, Isabella • as the briliant meteor lighted me; her father tried to • ove her in my behalf in vain, for cold indifference perused in every leniament. Here comes the ruf
•• an crew, fell hate, and fixed defiance on their brows •• throned—approach ye demons, ye whose damning • oks would fright hell's cabinet, and fill the world • ith horror to behold thee.

lg.head: Chorus of Assassins.
lg.l: Outcast from all the world we are,
Against all human beings war,
Rapine or rape, 'tis all the same,
Plunder, and murder is our aim.
Incendiaries we are all,
The mother or the infants squall,
No weight impresses on our heart,
Tho' racks reward us with its smart.

div.head: SCENE III.—In Padua.—A room in CELIO'S house.

sp.speaker: ISABELLA.
sp.p: The stifling flame rekindles, quickened by sighs flashes thro' my whole frame—the time so slowly glide away—each day to me is a year—each hour a month Oh, Henry why dost thou stay so long away? wer • thou fledged with the plumes of love; swift as a beard • ed Flecta thou would'st fly into my longing arms▪ But much I fear, when thou dost return, my sire wil • not let thee to my prison room.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Well my child, how passes time away?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Sadly indeed!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Right—so should it pass indurance. Wha • is the cause but thy disobedience? consent, alone, t • be Lorenzo's wife, shall ever set thee at liberty.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Yes, death will set me free!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Fear not, thy death is not yet so near; th • pretty face accords well with drooping melancholy.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Lorenzo's my relative.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: No nearer than a cousin. Florella, when b • troth'd to him, made no such peevish plea.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Oh my poor sister! for her untimely death grief finds its vent in tears! (weeps·)

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: 'Twas heavens decree.

sp.speaker: Isab·
sp.p: Could heaven ordain, that to much pie •• should be sacrificed? Lorenzo himself, confessed, th •• in the midnight hour, they alone, where on the vesse • deck, when she by accident was drowned; this sto •• does not link together well; though none have y •• spoke dubious of its truth, I most strongly think▪

sp.speaker: Celio.
sp.p: You do not think so! make him happy w •• deserves thee; who deserved, and wo • Florella, b • fa • e forbade their unity.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Though he were the only man on earth, never would call him husband.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Then shal't thou not call me father; hear my malediction! if thou still art obstinate, by hea
• en, I'll cast thee off forever, nor will I own thee as my child again.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
That I could bear; but 'tis cruelty when • arents for lucre, make a traffic of their offsprings • eace! cast me forth in the wide world alone; and in • ome wild I'd stalk with naked fee • , untill with bri
• rs and with splinters torn, the gushing blood would • eave a trail behind! some running stream would moist my fever'd lips, and my parched tongue, would • oon find great releif! at night I would lay me down • o rest, a stone my pillow, or the naked earth; no • overing but the heavens to shield me! so each suc
• essive day my time shall pass, till nature wearied • nd exhausted quite, resign myself a willing martyr, • ather than be wedded to Lorenzo!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I've heard your resolution; now farewel!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: (detaining him) Yet one word more my • ather! I had a mother! thou didst dearly love her.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: (affected) Why dost thou bring to my mind fresh, the loss of that precious treasure, which was dearer to me than my own existence?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Dost thou remember her last dying words?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Her dying words? (affected.)

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: A most affectionate, maternal, charge she gave me; and her last, last words to thee were, give • er to the man of her choice.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I must not hear you! (going)

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
(with encreased emotion.) You must not leave me yet—I see you are moved—tears from your eyes •• art forth, pity's remonstrance! (kneels and takes • old of his • obe. His face averted.) as you loved • er, and her last words, when in yours, her most •• feless hand you pressed; you did not answer, for • our heart was full, labouring for vent; but indeed,
your eyes spoke, and put the seal of heaven upon it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Isabella! no more!—

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: I'll tell you all; then as a menial beggar, spurn me from you; my plighted vow is given to another.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: What sayest thou!

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: To that gentleman who saved me from the ruffian's arms. — With what valour did he face the cursed band and beat them down: then for the first time love lighted his torch within my breast, and ever since has flamed unbounded; you gave him welcome to your house, he left us, soon to return again; our hearts in mutual contact beat, and in heavens register our faith's enroll'd! Gratitude—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Gratitude, might turn the ballance in his favor were he of our country born.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: That matters not, the generous heart that beats with transport for a fellow creature's welfare, the country to whom he owes his birth, is rich indeed that can boast many such.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Your arguments are vainly used; you've nearly brought my feelings to an ebb.—But my will you've heard, if you love your father, be wise, and take his council.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Stay yet a moment longer—no, he is gone, and I am left more wretched than before; ſhould I remain here, when my Henry returns, farewell hope; then despair to you I trust!— Exit.

div.head: SCENE IV—A grove,—Enter WALTER & HENRY.

sp.speaker: Walter.
sp.p: Here we are at last, and no sign of my antagonist yet; 'tis past the hour appointed.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: (looking at his watch.) We have five minutes yet to spare. What think you of the Italian ladies? you had a spec • men last night.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
There is something in the Italian ladies so
wanton, it sets me in a blaze; the sight of one of them sets my heart thumping for an hour. [Enter LORENZO and PEDRAS with Assasins; they place them in ambush.] Gentlemen, your most obedient, I think I have seen thy visage once before, Lorenzo?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Right or wrong you are determin'd to fight?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What think you I came for.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: To ask my pardon for your unwarrantable challenge? but if I must send you to explore the lower regions, draw quickly: for I have no time to lose.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Ha assassins! villain thou dy'st. (Lorenzo and Walter fight. Lorenzo is run through the body and falls, Assassins rush upon Walter and Henry; during the contest several of them are killed, the rest fly; at that moment the curtain drops. Music during this business.)

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I.—A room in FLAVIO's House.

sp.speaker: FLAVIO
sp.p:
Here have I wearied my aged limbs, pacing with anxious steps, in expectation of my childs return; some accident sure has happened, she would not have staid thus long else to torture her father's heart; some sad omen shakes my decayed frame, and tells me we shall not meet again. Last night when rosy slumbers stole upon my care-worn mind, methought Phoebus in splendor ne'er had shone so bright; all the earth seem'd richen'd with his orient beams; when soon and sudden, as if nature revolted and hurl'd black curtains 'twixt the sun and earth, flashes of streaming fire
burst through his contending screens, and waters gush'd, as if to drown the earth! the savage beasts for shelter ran precipitate with horrid yell from place to place, and heaven's feathered couriers with expanded wings floated breathless down the engulphed precipices!—A ship then appeared in view tossing among the billows, she dashed against the rocks; in that dire moment the schrieking of the victims rous'd me from my lethargy, and it struck so strong impression on my senses, that for some time I thought 'twas real.
Enter SERVANT hastily
—Why this haste?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I am sorry, but Florinda!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Speak, but say she's alive.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: She is not dead.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Where is she? what has happen'd? instantly ease this anxious heart.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Florinda, and Celio your brother, after a narrow escape by the assistance of two noble gentlemen have safely landed. I was dispatch'd to give you notice.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Speak! let me hear what has happen'd;

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
When gliding through the water with a gentle breeze, a cloud appeared, but no danger seemed to threaten; and as it imperceptibly approach'd, an envious flaw upset your Gondola, and all were threatened with a wa •• y grave. Florinda then more frighten'd than the rest, being less able to support herself, for some short time most pitiously shriek'd aloud, imploring help; two strangers from a boat close by, plunged into the water and arrived to Celio's and Florinda's help, whose body's were disappearing; Florinda for a while was lost, so was one of the strangers, he brought her from the bottom, I beheld her in one arm quite lifeless borne; while the other gentleman
assisted Celio, and we were soon all taken on bo • rd our preservers boat.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Oh my prophetic dream! who are those strangers that thou talk'st of?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I cannot tell, they are not of this country born.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Whoe'er they are, this generous act does shew their nobleness of soul, and the preservers of my child and brother, shall find my gratitude will not be bounded. (Enter FLORINDA, CELIO, WALTER, HENRY, and Attendants. Florinda rushes into Flavio's arms, they embrace in speechless rapture.) My child! my Florinda! and do I then from the grave embrace my child. (Turns to his brother.)— Celio what miracle hath preserved thee?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Florinda and myself, to those worthy gen
• lemen owe our lives; they leap't into the jaws of death to save us.

sp.speaker: Flav·
sp.p:
Welcome my friends, my preservers, for • o I shall ever call ye;—This house is thine, and all that it contains. Which of those two gentlemen pre
• erved my child?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Neither; to providence who ever protects the innocent you are indebted, not to us.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: From your ready, ingenious, generous answer, you are the preserver of my child. (To Henry) You the preserver of my brother; my study shall be • ver how to cancel the debt of gratitude I owe you.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
'Tis already cancelled; for the joy, the heart felt joy of rescuing a lovely female from de
• truction, vibrates with such emotion in my breast, • feel myself indebted for the opportunity.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Indeed you wrong yourself; but during our stay in Padua, my house must be your home— • cannot take a denial.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
'Twould be an ill compliment indeed for
us to refuse your candid invitation, I answer for my friend.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you doubtless need refreshment, and likely you wish to be alone, we'll therefore leave you for a short time together.— Exeunt all but Henry and Walter, Florinda last.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Well Walter we are in a devil of a predicament at present.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: How so my friend?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Do you recollect my telling you of a beautiful lady to whom I had paid my addresses in this place?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: (alarmed.) This is not I hope—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Why are you in love with her?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I knew what you would say, I now am the most miserable of mortals; were any body my rival but yourself, I could have endur'd it with greater fortitude; but she has your heart; whether or no, to you my friend I resign my claim; you have the prior right.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Ha, ha. ha,—Walter I did not think you had got touched so soon.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Don't laugh at me. (looks dejected.)

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: You remember laughing at me on the same subject I suppose.—But our business is of a nature something serious, which when known may be attended with dangerous consequences.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Oh that I had never seen her!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Then you would not have sav'd her.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: That confutes me—Oh love! love! how powerful is thy operation!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Did you ever see any thing that wore a petticoat but you fell immediately in love with it?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: That was love of a more vulgar specie, this is as different as day-light and darkness—full of the most tender refined feelings. Oh that you were not my rival!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I am not your rival.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Is it not to her then that—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: No on my soul.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: [Exultingly.] Then I am completely happy; • ay what you will you cannot hurt me now. (Enter waiter with wine.)

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Before I proceed, a toast—may America, whose basis is virtue, soar uncontaminated above the • actious enemies of its Independence. [drinks.]

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: [Drinks.] [they fill again.) I should have • oasted cupid; but I ought never to forget the land of my nativity. I'll drink to the memory of America's •• lustrious chief—the immortal Washington! [both • rink.]

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Now to my story. This Celio is father to Isabella, my fair enchantress; he is brother to Flavio; • nd Flavio is father to Lorenzo, who fell beneath • our sword.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Good Heaven! [much agitated.]

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I had no oportunity of telling you this • efore.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: And I am the murderer of this good man's • on, and shall the murderer find refuge under the •• thers roof?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: You are no murderer! you saved his daughter!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
O, had the son inherited one spark of the • onor which blazons in every word and action of his • re, I would have been proud indeed, to own him for brother, tho' in the grave; he was brother to Flo
•• nda, him I have killed, and her I have saved from • eath. But for her to call me, by the tender name 〈◊〉 husband, that killed her brother, that can never be!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Consider of the vile cause in which he fell.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: All, all I grant, and Flavio's pardon I •• uld no doubt obtain, if he should know the real •• use, but for his, and his daughters sake, that must • e never known to him.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: We'll leave the house immediately.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Let me advise; 'twould be better that we stay a few days, f • r fear of suspicion; your ready acceptance of his invitation; our intention, stayin • some weeks in Padua, you told to Celio.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I am bewildered, do thou direct me.

div.stage: Enter FLAVIO in tears, with a letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Oh my son! my son Lorenzo!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: [aside.] 'Tis as I expected, the news ha •• already arrived. Shall I discover myself to him?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: As you value your life do not.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I will. Let fate do with me what it may▪

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: I have a son! excuse these tears; an unfortunate son! who fell by an unknown person • hand, nearly deprived of life.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: [aside.] Then he is not dead! kind fortune, for that I thank thee. Is his recovery expected▪

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Engaged in a duel, he received a deep though not a mortal wound, (tis hoped • from his adversary; should he recover, he will • oon be here with Don Pedras, his friend.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: The person is now under your own roof, from whom your son received his wound.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: You astonish me! What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I am that person; he received his woun • from no hand but mine.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: I cannot believe—though I know not why you should tell me false.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Flavio you doubt. I was second to my friend on the unfortunate occasion.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I wish a hearing before you condemn me truth shall dictate my tongue. I will tell the re • cause without abatement of the smallest circumstanc •

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p:
Let us then to the adjoining chamber, a •• there before my child and brother relate the whole. Though death to my son had been the result of the
•• arrel, I must still have looked upon thee as th •
• eserver of my child Florinda.

div.head: • CENE II—Severe lightening, Thunder, rain and high winds.—Inside of a ROBBER'S CAVE. A • amp suspended by a chain, casts a dim light throughout the gloomy cavern. Guns, Pistols, Swords, &c. • a • e hanging in different parts of this dreary vault.— The Banditti drinking and carrousing.

lg.head: A GRAND CHORUS BY THE BAND.
lg.l: The whistling winds, the washing rain,
The distant thunders roar,
While we the traveller do • btain,
To rob him of his store.
Tho' death surround us we'll not fear,
No danger do we know,
Priestcraft is treason to our ear,
We fear no future woe.
At midnight some will go to rest,
Stretch'd on a flinty stone;
The owl is screeching in her nest,
While others they are gone,
Exploring paths in woods to fright,
And plunder all they meet;
Though lightning's flash does dim our sight,
We none do fear we meet.
So now to rest our wearied bones,
We'll lay ourselves along,
Upon this vaulted cavern's stones,
To which we all belong,

div.stage: • anditti lay themselves down in different parts of Cave.)
Enter Don PEDRAS very melancholy; arms folded, hi • eyes bent to the ground; a dreadful crash is heard be • arts and looks round wildly.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What a tremendous shock! What blue vivid s • r •• ks of light!— (The storm abates.)—To wha • a desperate fortune was I born! (pauses.) The nigh • is now far spent, the Wolf, in hungry tone for prey is howling loud amid he tumultuous elements; the screeching owl upon the leafless spray, in discor • grates the ear; and, to imagination, the yawning graves gape wide, and sepu • chres their gnashing spec • res send from worlds unknown with horrible profusion!—This rocky mansion, deep cavern'd in the cliff, owns me for its master, and many dire villai • with me leagu'd, from the world outcast, inur'd 〈◊〉 toil and barbarous assassination!—Oh could I retrac • my steps! that is impossible. If like Byblis I coul • weep 'twould not wash my sins away; 'twould only mock my own despair! If at this late period of life heaven would forgive my sins, I'd yield my body 〈◊〉 its mother earth, and the most tormenting • angs 〈◊〉 death would be light to what I here on earth endure▪ For eight long years have I been Captain of this cu • throat assembly; none yet has found me cut, not eve • Lorenzo my bosom friend, have I entr • sted.—Th • storm is hush'd; no more blue lightenings now wi • thwart me in my walk—The verdant leaves upon t •• towering oak row newly wash'd, will give a whol • some scent, and make meditation sweet.— Exit.

div.stage:
A noise. Whis • le is heard. Part of the Band bei •• upon a scout find OBADIAH AMINIDAB BROA •
BR • M, and bring him in the Cave. The band •• rise.

sp.speaker: 1st. Robber.
sp.p:
Come along you hypocritical broa •
brim shaker.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Yea; verily I say unto thee, I have no more • ieces of silver.

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: Damme but you have got gold mayhap, and •• at will do as well. Come, come don't be bashful • ff with your clothes.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Wouldst thou have me naked? then the wife • f my bosom would know me not.

sp.speaker: 3d.
sp.p: We'll leave you your shirt, for I like to be •• cent d • mme.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I perceive thou dost▪—thou art a decent •• uth!

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: Come come, off with your breeches, and • our coat.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
If thou layest violent ha • ds upon my breech
•• thou wilt behold nothing but nakednes; and when return unto Tabitha the wife of my bosom she would •• ke advantage of my lamentable situation, and smite • e sore; which though against my persuation would • ake me to dance, yea verily outrageous would I • ance to Tabitha's music!

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: Then I see force must be us'd.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Stay friend, stay, I have something to say • o thee, will melt thy heart to pity!

sp.speaker: 3d.
sp.p: You'd be puzzled to do that.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: "A man may catch cold while his breeches • mending," but if he waits 'till he getteth a new • ir 'twil • give him a sore throat.

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: Come my hearties we'll give this chap a trial, • ppoint a judge, and a lawyer to plead on each side.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: "You cannot make a silken purse out of a • w's ear."

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: You shall be judge. (To one of the Band.)— You have got the biggest belly.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: "Fat paunches make lean pates," I choose • hin, wise, discree • man, that will do justice.— (Points to one very emaciated.)

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: He has been sick for a month; he's nothing but skin and bone, he wont speak ten words in an hour.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: "Many words do not fill a bushel."

sp.speaker: 2nd,
sp.p: A dam'd impudent quaker as ever I knew.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I talk of chalk and you of cheese.

sp.speaker: 4th.
sp.p: I'll be your lawyer.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: "Proffer'd service stinks,"—I'll plead my own cause.

sp.speaker: 1 st.
sp.p: I'll be lawyer in defence of the state, so no more of your jawing tacks old fellow 'till we begin; big belly sit you there—Broadbrim s • and you there— (raises him on a stone, the Band arrange themselves on each side.) G • mmen of the Jury—

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: "Every man thinks his own Geese Swans."

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: I believe it be my turn to speak first Mr. Lawyer.—Gemmen of the Jury, what do you think of this dam'd impudent fellow now before you?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: That's me. What dost thou most honorable Judge and Jury lay to my charge?

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: In the first place we rob'd • im.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: "Give him rope enough and he'll hang himself."

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: But the heaviest charge your honor, is, after we took from him what money he had, we could find no more.

sp.speaker: Judg.
sp.p: Give me the sum. (The money is given to him.)

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: "The receiver is as bad as the thief."— Restore it unto me, restore it to its rightful owner, and thou shalt be rewarded tenfold.— (aside.) —With a halter each I verily hope. Then acquit the jury, "where vice goes before, vengeance followeth after."

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: How many were concern'd in robbing this fellow?

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: There were four of us.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: "Many hands make light work."

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: But I could have done it as easy alone.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Thou could'st not friend.

sp.speaker: 2nd
sp.p: What! do you challenge me?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: If I had thee alone with my money in thy •• cket, I would struggle with thee—yea verily I • ould struggle with thee hard!

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: Mr. Judge do you hear this?

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: He is right.

sp.speaker: 1st.
sp.p: I think for my part we ought to give him a •• od flogging and let him go.

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: I'll give it him alone.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Bravo! bravo! come down, come down.

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: (Strips himself ready for fighting.) I like to have like a gemmen, I take no advantage, you • y strip likewise.

sp.speaker: Ami.
Judge.
sp.p: Your money back, and go about your ••• iness.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Then I will buffet with iniquity.
[Is stript.] Come make yourself ready, off 〈◊〉 your coat.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I can smite thee sore with my robes wrapt 〈◊〉 me.
Come on then. [Aminidab advances in a 〈◊〉 pace, and turns one cheek towards him, which • trikes with his hand,]

The spirit beginneth to move. (Turns the 〈◊〉 cheek, which he strikes likewise. AMINIDAB,
〈◊〉 till now kept his hands before him, raises his right 〈◊〉 and with a severe blow fells him lifeless to the ground.)

There is your money. (throws the purse 〈◊〉 .)
Banditi shout, Bravo! bravo! bravo!

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: "Save a thief from hanging and he will cu •• your throat." He did provoke me to wrath, and I could not abide it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Judge.
sp.p: He is not kill'd quite, is he?

sp.speaker: 3d.
sp.p: Oh no! pour a b • ttle of rum down his throat, and he'll come too in a twinkling. (Pour • rum in his mouth.)

sp.speaker: 2nd.
sp.p: (rising.) Oh dam the Quaker! (they carry him off. A whistle is heard.)

sp.speaker: 3d.
sp.p: What somebody else▪ no more sanctificatio • I hope.

sp.speaker: 5th.
sp.p: Off with your cloaths, you have more money▪

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Who is your Captain!

sp.speaker: 5th.
sp.p: As brave a man as ever cut a throat.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: 5th.
sp.p: Nigh enough for you, my tight one. Yo • unruly temper must be curbed; the bastinadoes mus • be your lot for supper. Comrades, suppose we tie hi • up, and give him a few stripes, 'twill do his bod • good, 'twill allay his choler.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Agreed! (they attempt to seize him, 〈◊〉 snatches a pistol from the ground.)

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Stand off! the man that stirs one step to • wards me dies!

sp.speaker: 6th.
sp.p: Have at you then, my tight lad. (Lore ••• kills him, and the rest rush upon him.)

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What alarm is this?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Surely I should know that voice.

sp.speaker: 5th.
sp.p: This villain has shot one of our best co •• rades dead.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Away with him to the rack! tear hi • by p • ecemeal. How happen • d all this?

sp.speaker: 5th.
sp.p:
Captain I'll tell you. As we were on o •
•• out, not far from this, the other side the hill, we • ized him, got some money, suspecting he had more, • e were determined to bring him before your honour, •• en soon as he entered, in a devil of a fury, grap
• ed one of the pistols, and said the first that ad
•• nced towards him should die upon the spot. When •• bio, who long since has had the credit of being • e best Robber in our band, endeavoured to seize 〈◊〉 , whom he instantly shot dead.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Then let the rack appease our Fabio's manes: • t tear out his tongue!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Can I believe my eyes? Can it be possible, • n Pedras is captain here?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Away with him!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
[With great emotion.] Yes away with 〈◊〉 ! tear out my tongue, quick! Then place me on the • eel! Let me be an age in torture! Let thy heavy • ns break the bones of him, whose friendship for • e would never have ceased till death! root out my • s, and in their bleeding sockets pour hot burning 〈◊〉 ! then my last dying groans, shall call down cur
• on Don Pedras' head, with dreadful echo through 〈◊〉 dreary vault!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: [Confused and abashed.] Lorenzo!

You know me—well enough you know me. 〈◊〉 in this world my time is short; to the last will prove thy treachery! Is this the friendship thou • essed for me? Here a Captain of Banditti, with 〈◊〉 hired slaves to entrap thy deareſt friend. What 〈◊〉 I done, Don Pedras, to merit this from thee?
I am all astonishment! Lorenzo I never • ht thy life, but to the laſt would have ſtood •• xt thee and any harm, but—

sp.speaker: • or.
sp.p:
But, what? excuse not thy perfidy, ungrate
• an.

Lorenzo, hear me; ſhou • dst thou condemn then I have done. (to Banditti.) Withdraw
awhile, and leave to me this ſtranger. (they with draw.) I knew not that they had seized and brough • thee hither, till thy declamatory speech—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why are those base wretches under th • command?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Thy friendſhip I eſteemed, and looked upo • thee as my only real friend; but now to clear my self—I muſt contaminate the air, with that which f •• many years has been mouldering in my cankered brea •

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What is it you mean? be quick to tell me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Wonder not, shouldst thou behold tears star •• ing from my eyes 'ere I have done. Eight yea • have now elapsed, since when all the world was 〈◊〉 silence bush'd, and none bore witness but the silv •• moon, who trembling stood in expectation th • some favouring cloud would screen her from the ho • sight!—every night that I behold her now, she see • to accu • e me.—O! could I spare myself the dread • reci • al!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Go on. (anxiously.)

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
I loved a maid, of parentage none m • oppulent—O faithless woman! each moment I passe • when not with her seemed to me miserable indeed. I had her parents sanction to my love; likew ••• her's—the happy day was fixed—the night previ • to performing the intended nuptial ceremony, I w • to her father's house, quite unexpected, for I had out to invite some friends, a little distant, but 〈◊〉 carriage breaking down, I perforce returned; innocent old sire told me his daughter 〈◊〉 a • one in the garden, taking the evenings refre ••• ing breeze, and requested me to join her. For some time I paced the garden round, and n •• ing could perceive, searching each arbour, hoping find my love; at last I heard the voice of a ma • a low whisper; not even then did I suspect Amen an answer from a female struck me dumb, and lik •
• tue fixed, I stood immoveable knowing the voice • be her's! soon as from my astonishment I recover'd, • lowly crept, guided by their whisper, till I placed • yself behind the very bower where those two lovers 〈◊〉 ; by the moons light, I behold them lock • d in each • ers arms, he stealing the nectar from off her ruby 〈◊〉 ; she told him the only cause why she gave her con
• t to marry me, was that by him she was pregnant, ••• wing that each convenient time when I should be • ent, to grant him still the priviledge he had 〈◊〉 often taken! Oh! then what fiery indignation 〈◊〉 disgust possess'd my every faculty!—nor could I •• rce collect myself but to believe 'twas all a dream. • is night said she, will be the last that we'll be in
• ate, untill I lay in the arms of Don Pedras. Before 〈◊〉 eyes he clasp'd her round the waist, and tasted • t bliss ineffable that I so long impatient waited for; • hat dire moment, did I send them both to fathom
• perdition! I drew my sword, and with one thrust • rced to the heart, my faithless love, and by ad
• g to my name, that of Fratricide, I have forfeited 〈◊〉 my peace of mind this side the grave, for he I 〈◊〉 sacrificed, was my only brother!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Didst thou know him to be thy brother, thou didst kill him?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
No, not till after the fatal blow was struck. • that I had died, e'er my arm had been raised to • mit so fell an act. I had the steel already raised, 〈◊〉 reeking with my brothers blood, and that of 〈◊〉 more dear than life I loved, to strike in my own • om! but the almighty willed it otherwise — my • es relaxed, and forgot their office—I had not the • er to revenge their deaths. 'Twas then I swore, • e revenged on man; therefore, this band of • oes have I selected, where in this craggy cave I 〈◊〉 , with them at intervals, but, to torment mankind 〈◊〉 make them wretched as myself. You alone, do
count my friend, for you I'd lay down my life.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Did you never confess your guilt?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Never to a human being, untill now, I alarm • ed the family; not the least suspicion had they of 〈◊〉 guilt: the old man ran mad, and expired in a fe • days; her mother of a broken heart, died soon; a • all were buried in one vault together.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
I wonder thou hast never told me this bef •••
▪

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Finding in this wicked age such dishonest that angels face with a devils heart; my own bro •••• to deceive me too; meth • ught then honesty a pl • thing, for saints to make a jest of. Canst thou fo • give me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: An unmeaning insult forgives itself. 〈◊〉 to see thee in a place like this, afflicts me much.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: All I grant, is infamous indeed. But ca • thou still look upon me as thy friend?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: On one condition.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Name it?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: That you desert these felons.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Should I do so, they would betray me, a • a death of infamy, would be the consequence.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I know not how to advise. We will confe •• and on something determine, e're we return fr •• Padua. The wound I received is now so well I thi •• I may with safety venture.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: We will loose no time in hastening o • departure. (Pedras sounds his whistle. Banditti rise a • come forward. An Earthquake is heard. Thun ••• and Lightning.) Hark! the storm again begins!

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: The distant thunder's roaring, the blue lightnings vivid fl •
And • ockey mountains fall from high, hark! hark! 〈◊〉 dreadful crash;
The earth does tremble beneath us, oh! pardon us our si •
Oh ye G • ds! the caveit falls,
On our heads! oh! save our souls!

•• av • n have mercy! pardon our sins!
Back part of the Cave falls, with a dreadful 〈◊〉 ; through the vacancy is seen a Vulcano, emitt
• fire, red hot stones, sulphu • , &c.
〈◊〉 earthquake's uncap'd the mountain's top, see fire •• rsting forth!
〈◊〉 burning lumps of sulphur are bel • h'd from out the earth,
〈◊〉 f • rmament seems all on fire, the red hot stones do fall,
Here and there, every where,
Whilst the earth en • ombs us all.

sp.stage: • The earth opens and swallows up part of the band; rest exit with Lorenzo & Pedras.)

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I—Padua, a room in FLAVIO'S house.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Now Florinda, what suit is this?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Tis a foolish one indeed, and I dare say • en I tell you what it is, you'll only laugh at me my offici • usness.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Tell me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I know you will say I am in love but I •• w I am not.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: What;

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Do not look so severe at me.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Say on.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I only wish to intercede in behalf of your 〈◊〉 guests, that on account of the foolish quarrel they • e had with my brother▪ they may not leave us • n he arrives.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p:
Your brother Lorenzo, and his friend Don
Pedras have arrived already, and all is amicably settled.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Arriv'd! Oh when?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Even now. I left them in the adjoining chamber.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Is he quite recover'd then?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: His countenance is somewhat changed.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: They now no more are enemies. I rejoice to hear it.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Lorenzo confess'd himself in fault.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Let me hasten to congratulate him on his preservation.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Stay, they beg'd the time alone. Why shouldst thou become the mediator of those strangers?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Have I not a cau • e? Would it not be unkind to let them leave the house 'till they depart from Padua entirely?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: (aside.) I fear her interest is turn'd to something more tender—'Tis gratitude you feel.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I dont know what it is, but I never felt so in my life before. I like Henry—

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: I thought Walter—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I was going to say, I like Henry, and so I do Walter: but I think Walter the handsomest.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: I think not.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Henry preserved my uncle's life, for that, should I not be grateful? when I look at Walter, I feel gratitude, and something else, but that something is not love, for love they say, is a sensation of pleasure; now mine is different, for my heart makes such a thumping, whenever he speaks to me, I believe if he should talk long at a time, 'twould nearly kill me.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: (aside.) 'Tis as I suspected. But I will be sure, I'll try her friendship towards Pedras.—How do you like Don Pedras?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: He that is come to take possession of your hand and heart?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You are not really serious.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Fain would I think that you were not▪ you have often spoke of him, I ha • e as 〈…〉 that I detested even the sight of him.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: I will not insist upon your marrying him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Thanks! thanks my dear father, thanks!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: But you must take your choice, marry him, or have to husband▪

sp.speaker: Flor,
sp.p: I will have no husband then.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Or go • o a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: To a Nunnery! (affected.)

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Pedras, or the Nunnery. Farewell, and remember Pedras is of high birth and distinction;— marry him and you will be ever happy, I'll send him to you.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: O do not!—Well, I suppose he will come, and I must prepare to receive him.—How? in what manner? shall I intreat him not to persist in his addresses? no, that will encourage him to continue, hoping in time to make a conquest—that will never do!—When he comes I'll laugh at him, and then he will be glad to make a speedy exit. Birth, and distinction! empty baubles, like the dew, with the sunny beams, they waste away. Are we not all mortal? riches purchase titles, but titles cannot purchase wisdom; titles are set as baits for sycophants to bite at.

div.stage: Enter DON PEDRAS. FLORINDA looks dejected with face averted.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Why this pensive, thoughtless, listless state
my love? shouldst thou not fly with the wings of love, into thy Pedras' arms?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: O, is it you? I was thinking of something of consequence.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why so very grave?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: 'Tis a way I have, when people become troublesome.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Surely you cannot mean me, somebody affronted you before I came into the room.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You would wish to think so, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I cannot think otherwise, for surely you would not wish to make a sacrifice of him who lives but in thy smiles.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Could you not say something more flattering? could you not compare my eyes to stars, my brows to the arched heavens, my cheeks and lips to the damask rose; my teeth to ivory; my skin to monumental alabaster; my breath to jessamine?— Then you might have hopes. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Confusion!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: (mimmics him.) Confusion! make no apology. But why should so gallant a man as you be confus'd? a real man of spirit never is. Why don't you begin with your die-away speeches? lovers always pay compliments, deserving or not deserving they think we take them all—Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I love you—I sincerely love you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: (with affected gravity.) Do you really love me?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: By heavens!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: How do you feel when you are in love?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I feel a peturbation, and uneasiness in mind.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: (very seri • us.) I am in love.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Angelic sound! with me?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
By your description of the effects of love,
• t must be so, for I have been uneasy since I first • eard of your arrival, and still remain so; I shall not • el right I'm sure till—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Till when? [anxious.]

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Till you leave the room.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Is this then my reception? is this the return passion from a woman, whom I so sincerely lov'd?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No man on earth, do I more sincerely hate, • an thee Don Pedras.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Damnation. [exit.]

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, since laughing has so good an • fect, I will laugh him out of one room into another, • l at last, he will be very glad to quit the house en
•• rely. If my father insists upon my marrying him, • hat will become of me? Oh, here comes Walter.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
The quarrel between your brother and my
• f, is fairly settled.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: The joyful tidings reached my ear before • u came; my father—

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Would that I had brought it first.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: It gives me pleasure to announce any thing • t pleases you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I think I like you better than I ever did.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: My father has been here; he says I must • rry Don Pedras, or he'll send me to a nunnery.— • ould prefer you indeed.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Would you?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I think I should be always happy when you near me.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Florinda! [transported.]

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
The idea of leaving you, to be shut up in • loistered convent, hurt me so much, that when
Don Pedras came a wooing to me, I affronted him, and he left the room quite angry.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Is he then my rival? This candour compels me to tell you what a sacrifice you have made since the first time your eyes beamed their kindness on me, my heart within told me where'er I strayed, Florinda reigned sole umpire here. (Lays his hand on his heart.) And never till now, have I more then vented my passion with my sighs.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: [nearly weeping.] Will you, will you, protect me!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Should your father persist; to me if you fly for refuge, my arms shall open wide to give you welcome.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: But not to be dishonoured?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Witness for me heaven.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Whither would you conduct me?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: To America, my love, my native land, where liberty and love reigns, with uncontrouled dominion.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Though I love my reverend relatives much rather than forget you, I could leave them all, and range the wild and desolate scorching sands, or tos • forever on the foaming surge—then in each storm when destruction arround us threatens, and billow dash our shattered bark to pieces; in each others arm • embracing death—I would not envy any that I le • behind.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: O! exquesite transport!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Do not abuse my candour▪

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Abuse! forbid it heaven; every silver ton • that has escap'd thy lips, is imperishably grafted i • my heart.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I hear some one coming; farewell for th • present, we will talk more anon.— (Exit.)

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Adieu my love.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Success, my dear fellow, has crown'd my toil, notwithstanding Celio has denied me his house. I am now happy as a prince. Isabella has sent me a • etter; here it is my dear boy. (reads the letter.)

body.p: "Since your arrival, my father has confined me in a room, there to remain 'till I consent to marry Lorenzo; therefore come to my house at twelve this night, • nd we will consult our future fortune. Behind the • ouse there is a ladder, by which means you may with • afety enter my chamber; the window I will leave • pen to prevent mistakes. I would not put you to this • rouble, could I any other way admit you.

sp.p: What think you, am I not before you?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Not you indeed, we are only even; for my • harmer left the room as you enter'd. I've gain'd a • omplete victory, she capitulated without a summons.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: All honourable I hope.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Do you think that I mean otherwise.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p:
Your meaning I do not doubt is honorable, • ut 'tis necessary at times, a gentle hint should be • iven, lest hurried by youthful passions, the well meaning may be plung'd in guilt; though of a de
•• ghtful moment duration, is a sin of the greatest mag
• itude committed by man.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I like your sentiments, tho' something of a •• bertine myself; where I have been I left no proofs • ehind, that I could accuse myself of wronging the •• nocent.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p:
To take advantage of an innocent partiali
• y, which being fann'd by the breath of affection, • pens into that of love; the person so deprav'd, if
he casts a retrospective glance, on the beloved object who fell a victim to his perfidy, left to buffet the harsh world alone, robbed of that precious jewel, which all the riches of the eastern world could not purchase an equivalent, must be a hardened villain indeed, whose conscience would not recoil upon himself.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Enough of sentiment Mr. Moralist, if you please. Now for something of a more lively turn.— My Florinda has informed me Flavio insists upon her marrying Don Pedras, but I have nothing to fear, she will go with me whereever my will directs.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Are you sure of that?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Quite sure! her unaffected sorrow pierced my heart; the pearly drops stole from her lovely cheeks, as she vowed eternal constancy and love.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I do not doubt the affections of Isabella, and let us speedy as posible obtain their hands, and we will all embark for America together.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Does not your conscience which you so often speak of, prick you, when you think of stealing Celio's daughter?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: If I obtain her by her own consent, I have lawfully that, which I rescued from the ravishers gripe. But though I saved Celio's life, he refuses me admittance to his house, fearing his daughter most certain; many would accuse me of ingratitude, but when I have possession of Isabella, the debt is cancelled! will you accompany me with our servants at the hour appointed?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Ask what you will I am yours.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Armed with Cupid's dart, we fear no evil, From mortal man, or demi devil.

div.head: SCENE II.—A room in FLAVIO'S House.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Thou counsellest well, but to contrive their destruction—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: They both shall die! I never will brook a rival.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Nor I. What had best be done?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Poison is safest.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: We will keep up appearances of friendship. Rather overact our parts than our sincerity should be doubted. The night when we attempted to take Isabella by force, when so many of my friends were slain by this American, my rival, lives implacable still in my breast, and fires me to my revenge. By his interposition was I deprived of her. I had the good fortune to escape unknown, and still live to plot more mischief—to over turn their deep laid love plots by a speedy murther. Then my friend to crown the work, Florinda shall be thy reward, and Isabella mine.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Should I hope to gain her, I'd leave no plan unthought of, that might border on success; her disdainful reception of me this morning, almost drives me mad; and every idea is on Florinda and my detested rival. Farewell, I'll to my chamber, and dream of mischief till the morning. (EXIT.)

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
[looking after him with a contemptous smile.] Sound mayst thou sleep, had I my wish, indeed so sound, that thy immortal parts, the devil might call his own, before the morrows dawn. My friend! 'tis well enough to call thee so, till an oportunity invites to put it beyond thy reach to do me service or disservice. Oh Pedras, unfortunate for thee, that I have found thee out· I loved thee once, 'tis true, but now my mind is much altered. Hate is imperious, it scourges friendship from my bosom with a scorpion lash; and in its legitimate natal palace, uprears his usurping disloyal diadem. Should we succeed in exterminating our rivals; Don Pedras, I will take good care, shall not outlive their deaths so long as to take my sister to his bed.—The family to be poluted by him! yet am I not
equally as bad? aye worse, if possible! but still unknown to all but Pedras. Truly, the two Americans have but little cause to believe me honest, but for their own sakes, they will not tell how basely they were treated by me. Don Pedras appears to me a faithful friend—so do I to him. He like myself, may wear the mask of friendship only, which now necessity commands; be that as it may, I am resolved, fix'd, and imovable—though remorse increase, as sins accumulate, I cannot now avoid the worst.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: My Brother! I have long'd much to see you—you look quite alter'd.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I am out of all danger—the wound I received, though deep, toucht no vital part; and by a Surgeon's timely aid I soon got better.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Indeed! I am rejoiced to hear it, I could not content myself 'till I had seen you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: And I am happy, in seeing time, so favourably has wrought a lovely impression on thy countenance.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I wish you to speak in my behalf; the joy of seeing you, put it almost out of my head.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Any think in Lorenzo's power—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: I do not doubt it. I wish you to pacify my father; and intercede for me with him, He is very angry with me because I do not love Don Pedras, who I think looks like a very wicked man.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Does he insist upon your marrying him?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Oh no, he does not insist, he gives me a choice.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why, that is generous!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Don Pedras, or the Nunnery. Will you not disuade him from so severe a sentence? I like your enemy, that was, very much.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: For what do you love him?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Did he not save my life?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: That is but gratitude, he rais'd his hand against mine.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: You confess'd yourself in error, and you now are friends▪

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I do not plead in Don Pedras's cause, I do not wish either to become thy husband.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Hear then, the fate of the ill starred maid:

lg.head: SONG—FLORINDA.
lg.l: IN Venice dwelt a peerleſs maid,
Her birth distinction did allow,
Her father fearful she'd degrade,
His honour'd house by one too low;
He bent his mind, on one of birth quite great,
To be for life, his lovely daughter's mate.
Poor hapless girl, already she,
Had given her virgin heart to one,
Of Plebeian rank, and low degree,
But mind magnanimous had grown;
When to her father's ears, this marriage came,
He spurn'd her forth, to penury and shame.
In durance vile her husband sent,
In chains he pin'd his life away,
His wife now starving does lament,
And houseless walk the livelong day;
By charity alone she got her bread▪
One morning in the street, she was found dead.
A living infant at her breast,
Was nurtur'd by the mother still,
Her father made of this a jest,
But he was punis'd, hear the will;
His house with elemental fire, was burn'd,
Among the ruins, he next day was found.

div.head: SCENE III—(Time night.) The outside of CELIO'S House, very magnificent. Iron fence, the large Iron gate wide open. Two lamps each side the gate are lighted.
div.stage: Enter WALTER and HENRY, with SERVANTS.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Thus far all is safe enough—the gate is open, punctual to her word—but I do not much like those lighted lamps.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: You need apprehend no danger of a discovery, for every thing is silent.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I perceive there are two windows open, likely they both lead into my Isabella's chamber.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: You mistake, for lo a light breaks through only one.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: That must be her's, she has lighted the room for fear I should mistake.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: T'would be a commical joke should it be old Celio's chamber.

sp.speaker: Hen▪
sp.p: What is the hour?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: (goes up to the lamps and looks at his watch.) 'Tis twelve by my watch—the city clock has not yet struck.
We will now search for the ladder she spoke of in her letter. (Exit on the opposite side that they entered.)

div.stage: CELIO with nightgown and cap, appears at his window.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
Methought I heard somebody's voice under my window, speaking in a low tone! 'tis somewhat strange at this late hour! I see nobody! whoever they may be, they are after no good, I will be
sworn. (looks round.) All is silent—could I be deceived? could it be fancy? it must be so, (Celio disappears.)

div.stage: ISAB •• LA appears at her window. Clock strikes twelve.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: The clock has struck, and no appearance of my Henry ye • ; could he have forgot the time? Oh! should he not come to night, my hopes will be forever blighted! (Celio appears at the window.)

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Isabella!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: (looking around alarmed.) Did you call? (sees Celio.)

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: For shame child, you will be sick! shut • he window and go to bed. The night air is very bad.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
It being so intensely warm I could not sleep, • nd therefore I opened the window to enjoy the even
• ngs refreshing air.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Exactly my case.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: (aside.) If my Henry should come now, • twould ruin all. Had not you better go to bed?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Go you to bed. I shall not, this hour.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Do you go to bed, I intreat. The evening • amps, the wind wafts, and being to their prejudice • xposed, the relaxed fibers, sucks in the poisonous • ir▪ and shoot through the whole frame.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: If so, let me ask why thou dost at this late our, expose thyself?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: (aside.) How provoking! you should take more care than one that's young, the vital spirits of • ealthy youth renders the system impervious,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Why this anxiety? you were not wont to • e so extravagant in your arguments: you wish to be • ntirely alone, I suppose, to indulge your romantic • deas, and give room to your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
(aside.) No, but I would wish to give
thoughts to my room.—I intreat you to go in, 'tis indeed for your sake that—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Then for your sake shut the window, and go instantly to bed.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: The heat is suffocating!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Methought I heard somebody under my window; some robbers may hap, intending to run away with my estate, or ravish my daughter. In, in, I say!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: (aside.) Oh, misery! it must have been my faithful Henry that was here, and now is gone for means to ascend. Oh, how I tremble, lest some mischance may befal him.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: In, in, I say, don't you hear?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I will, but do you go first.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I will not, untill I see the last of you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Unfortunate hour, good heaven protect my Henry. (Isabella goes in, and shuts the window.)

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Isabella seems very strange and whimsical to night. Did I not know her honest, and the iron gate being so strongly barred, I should suspect some midnight visitors. (Isabella opens the window slowly, Celio observes it.)

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: What, open again?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: 'Twas the wind that forced it open, and to obey strictly your comand, I came to shut it. (aside.) Oh, how I tremble. (exit.)

div.stage: Enter HENRY, WALTER and SERVANTS, with ladder.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Ha! men with a scaling ladder. I'll watch their motions. (exit and leaves the window open after him.)

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p:
I am in luck to night. See, the other window is now shut, and none is open but my fair Isabella's. Place the ladder under the opened window. (they place the ladder under the window.) Now come hither, (all advance near the front.) do you all withdraw
with this my friend, and should any alarm be given, then run to my assistance; this precaution is necessary, for fear of surprise.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: (appears with a gun at the window.) I think I will surprise some of you. I'll give you a taste of my double barrel'd gun if you come here. (aside and withdraws.)

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Success attend you my dear fellow.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I will not keep you waiting long: (exit Walter and Servants.)

div.stage: Henry goes to the ladder; attempts to ascend—Celio presents his gun, and fires, but misses him—Celio cries, Thieves! Murder! Henry, alarmed at so sudden an attack, springs from the ladder—Servants rush out of Celio's house, and attack Henry—Walter and Servants come to Henry's relief—drives Celio's Servants off on one side—they make a precipitate flight on the other— Isabela screaming from the window during the bustle— Music through the scene.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I.—time Night—the Sea Shore.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Nights sable mantle now enrobes the world • the dashing waters seem to rip the shore, and ships deep freighted, plough the foaming main; where many innocents have closed their eyes in seas unfathomable. But oh, Florella! thy untimely death, would turn to tears, the flinty stones, and make all honest men look pale with horror. In cupid's chains once more I'm fettered, his magic shaft has pierced my heart so deep, nought but possession can exterminate. My rival, ha! my successful rival; while he lives, Lorenzo
dies—dies piecemeal. The goading thought still harasses my soul, stirs up fiery indignation strong within me, and flashes vindictive fury through my brain. One way to escape the labyrinth is left, to Isabella's maid I'll give all powerful gold, and she will aid me in my dark intent. At midnight, unexpected, to her chamber I will steal, when if she reject my suit, loves furious passion will thrice nerve my limbs, and she a victim to my love shall fall. (exit.)

div.head: SCENE II.—A room in CELIO'S House, in which ISABELLA is confined.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: The risk we've run was great, therefore our gates shall be double barred, that henceforth we may live free from the attack of midnight ruſſians, searching for their prey. Thy frght was great, but all is well again; prithee cast off that mournful veil, which clouds thy countenance, and look more lively, since the danger's o'er.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I cannot so soon get over the fear I had for your safety. [aside.] Henry where art thou now? perhaps he hath his mortal wound, and now expiring curses the hour he listened to me.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Isabella do not turn from me, but attend to what I am going to say, with an attentive ear, and mark me well—for it concerns your quiet, ever after.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Lorenzo loves you! the choice I did not intend to give you ever again. My brother Flavio offered Florinda to marry Don Pedras, or go to a nunnery. Now I give you your choice, to have Lorenzo, or go to a solitary convent, there to be immured for life?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Dissembling is vain, and but increases—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I cannot dissemble, I will never marry Signior Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Then to a nunnery you go.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: • e not so rash.—Oh, for pity!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Yes, such pity as to the dogs I'd show; marry him, and you will be ever happy—his fortune is great—a noble title too, which to posterity, would be handed down, and be an honour to your ancestors.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: My suit I'd move in Henry's favour, but that I know you would not hear me speak—he that saved me from the ruffians fangs, and likewise you from the jaws of death, you cruelly forbid your house.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: 'Tis because he loves you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: No stronger motive, nor so good a plea, can ever be found to make him welcome.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: This night is your last under my roof, 'tis no punishment to confine you here, your disdain of Lorenzo when he came to visit you, with a lover's fondness; you shall repent, and at last be glad to accept of his proffer'd hand!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Never would I have believed from any one else, tho' they had sworn it, that you would thus have sacrific'd my peace forever. Never! never, will I give him my hand! sooner would I in charnel houses dwell, and rest my limbs upon the worm-eaten bones of mouldering mortals; in preference to the embrace of a loathsome man, who is an enemy to nature's sacred laws.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: That is really as pretty a speech as tho' you had study'd to make an answer for me. Farewell; 'till the morning here you stay, after which you know your doom. (Exit.)

sp.speaker: Isa
sp.p:
What will now become of me? my Henry I'm thankful escap'd unknown; I hope unhurt; I will persuade my father to let me pass one day more
under his roof, promise to marry Lorenzo, get Henry to come at night when all is silent, once more! Oh no, that is impossible now, the gates are doubly barred, and guarded too! Well is there no other way? must I submit to waste my days in solitary confinement, shut out forever from my Henry's sight? will heaven look on and suffer this?— (weeps, after some time speaks again.) I think I have hit upon a plan that may succeed; this room by that door leads into another; the windows of which open in the garden, could I but bribe my maid to make interest with the porter to leave the garden gate open—I could that way easily admit him, and he will release me from my prison. I will not loose a moments time—Lucetta—
Enter LUCETTA. Lucetta, to-morrow I leave you, this night is my lust in this house.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Whither are you going,

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: To a Nunnery!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Would I could help it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You can.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then tell me. If it is in my power depend upon my assistance.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Are you on good terms with the porter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Good terms? I guess so indeed, for we are as intimate as man and wife, as I may say.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Do you think? if you ask him, your influence is great enough to persuade him to leave the garden gate open.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Influence indeed!—what I ask of him he dare not deny, but I never request more than modesty will justify.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Here is a purse for yourself, here another for the porter.—Now I will write a letter for you to carry to my Henry. (sits down to write.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: (aside.) Ecod I'll keep both purses, and make the porter do what I like him to besides.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: (gives Lucetta the letter) Go now my faithful girl, deliver this to my love, and return soon as possible; but be careful that you are not discover'd by any body.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You need not caution me, 'tis not the first time by many. [aside.] The second bribe I have receiv'd this day; one from my lady, and one from Signior Lorenzo, who is to come in her chamber soon; what's his business with her, is none of mine, as long as I am paid—but I'm afraid he'll raise the devil with her. [exit.]

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Honest, faithful girl, I am now content,— I'll dream of nothing but my future happiness.

lg.head: SONG
lg.l: Oh time fly swiftly speed thy pace,
And usher in the light;
Then quickly Phoebus run thy rac •
Into the western night.
The silver moon will guide my love,
Safe in my longing arms;
He'll come like any turtle Dove,
Cooing with soft alarms.

div.stage: (Isabella throws herself on the Couch and sleeps.)

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Lo, on the downy couch her charms! who • ould resist so heavenly a form? her heaving snowy • reast might tempt a saint! Oh! that it were possi
• le some honest way to prove my true affections • ut am I not compell'd to this extremity? has she • ot treated me with deadly scorn? she has; and that • o me is excuse sufficient. When from her slumbers
awak'd, finding herself with me alone, she may alarm the house, and I be caught in mine own snare—I am impatient, yet dread the encounter. The fatal moment has at last arriv'd, that decides my happiness or my misery eternal— [goes to the couch, takes her hand and kisses it.] —Oh! enthusiastic kiss! still. still asleep!— [attempts to kiss her lips,—Isabella half rises up—appears terified.]

sp.speaker: Ias.
sp.p: What monster art thou?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No monster, but your willing slave.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: [starting from the couch.] Then instantly leave me, or I will alarm the house.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I will be civil.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Then shew it by leaving me. How came you here?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Love's torch guided me hither. O God, what tortures are there, so terrible, so tormenting, as uncontrouling passion?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Wretched Lorenzo!

sp.speaker: Lor.
