sp.p: I am indeed the veriest wretch that ever was created. Where you myriads of miles distant from me, never would I rest, or know repose, till I had you in possession. If you have the least pity or compassion, do not let me despair.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What's your business with me at this late hour? It does not signify an honest meaning—your countenance betrays your intentions; whatever they might have been, are now dishonorable and base; and had I ever harboured a thought to encourage you in your suit, this one attempt to blast my honour, would banish it forever from my bosom. [attempts to cross him to make her escape out of the door which Lorenzo entered.]

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Isabella, stay. [detains her.]

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: How, dare you stop me?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
I cannot answer you—I am so far advanced
I cannot now retreat—my shame you will disclose— my infamy, will be the sport of every bragadocia's tongue, and every menial wretch will point at me as I pass.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: If you do not let me depart, I will raise the house!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: [Takes out a pistol and presents to her. Isabella bursts into tears.] If you make the least noise, by which I shall be discovered, by heaven, you die.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What! would you have the heart to murther a defenceless woman? [after looking sometime at each other.]

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My fate is desperate! for a long time have I gazed upon those charms, which has kindeled a flame that almost consumer me! my temper is as inexorable, as the hyrcanian tyger. 'Twere best for you to save yourself! think of it well, for if you refuse me now your love, this minute shall be your last.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: (Eyes him with terror, and kneels.) Now inhuman savage! glut yourself with your own cousins blood.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: [aside.] I cannot! I thought no deed too bloody for me, now to act. No I will not kill thee; first will I improve the precious moment, then put a period to my own existence. (takes hold of her.)

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh, for heavens sake, have mercy!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Your struggling is vain. Dare not to cry for help.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Kill me! Oh, kill me, but do not use me thus.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Mine you shall be, tho' this embrace should be my very last. I will not loose this opportunity.— (clasps her.)

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh, Henry! Henry, where art th •• now?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Nay then! thus will I force you to my will. (the ghost of Florella appears, her face very pale, lips
blue, her eyes appear sunk in her head. The moment Lorenzo beholds her, he starts back, and is fixed like a statue of horror, eyeing the Spectre with rivetted attention, his whole frame appears convulsed, his breast thorbs quick—after same time, speaks wildly—music.) How differen • are mortals changed by death.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: At what gaze you, with such attention?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Florella, thy sister! behold her palid cheek.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Your crimes have drove you mad! do not harm me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I will not! pray leave me not alone. That face, that once astonished all the world, with its incomparable vivid hue, is now turned pale. Those socke • s, wherein brilliants darted their lustre, and far out shone the chrysolite, I behold no more. The felm curtain is let down. If they are in the bosom of the ocean lodged, that vast fountain will never again know night. Thy lips, once like the damask rose, is now the colour of the hyacinth! Oh, does she no • look pityful? what flinty substance would not dissolve in teas to behold her?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: What is the cause of this distemperature?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why hast thou come hither at this • ture Oh tell me the cause? I have not for six years • ehel • thee, untill now. Isabella, speak to her.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I look, where you direct your eyes so steady but I see nothing.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What, not see her? can it be my fanc • draws so perfect lineaments? Oh no, 'tis impossible (Florella disappears.) See where she goes! she's gone (Lorenzo lookes for sometime after the Spectre, the turns to Isabella.) I will now depart, and leave y • unmolested. Isabella, I have done thee wrong, cannot repair thy feelings, so much injured by m • But trust me, I am truly penitent.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh, leave me then!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I will. But let me take thy forgiveness with me?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I forgive you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Will you never tell this strange adventure?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I never will.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Nor expose my rashness, in which passion, hurried me beyond myself?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I promise.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Then all good angels guard thy slumbers. (exit.)

div.head: SCENE II.—A room in FLAVIO's House.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: We had a cursed time of it, sure enough, but, as we escaped with whole bones, we where lucky indeed. The letter I have now received, unravels the mystery. She says, Celio sitting up late, discovered her window open, which he commanded her to shut, but a few moments before we arrived.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: What more?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I had despaired, and given up all hopes, till I received this epistle. (reads.)

body.p: "If you will come by the back way, thro' the garden, to-morrow night, at the hour of twelve, bring with you some faithful friend, and a Friar, we may then be united. Tho' to-morrow, my father has decreed that I shall go to a nunnery, or accept Lorenzo's hand. I will dissemble, and chose the latter, to put off the time. My window is directly over an old dry well, you cannot mistake it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: [drops the letter by accident.] What think you? have I not all sure now?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
'Egad I think so indeed, your window
schemes I cannot say I am very fond of, but I am at your service. Flavio is obstinately bent upon Florinda's marrying Don Pedras or he'll send her to a nunnery likewise. She has solemnly promised to accept no hand but mine. You first make sure of Isabella, then will I marry Florinda. We must both • hare the same fate. I will wait for your success.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I have spoke to a Friar, whom I expect here every minute, to look into my wardrobe for a disguise, to prevent a discovery, which would prove fatal to the poor Franciscan.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Should you fail in this attempt—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: We cannot fail.—But here comes the right reverend father.
Welcome father, what news?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: We have no time for politics now.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: We will lose no time in equiping your holy ship, What masquerade, brave father, suits you best?

sp.speaker: Fir.
sp.p: Shew me thy wardrobe, and out of it, I will select something of the holy order.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: (opens closet.) Take your choice of my whole wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: (in turning • ver several dresses finds a Devils head with horns.) Surely satan hath been among you.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: The best disguise in the world,

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Fye, fye son, would you have one of the holy order of Francisco, where the robes of the seducer of all—for shortness called the devil. (pulls out the body, breeches with a tail, and cloven foot.) Oh, mercy, defend me! here is all the devil, sure enough.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: So the inside is pure when you put it on, the devil will do you no harm, for 'tis only his skin.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Well son, if you will have it so—

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Succeed in this and I will make your fortune old boy.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Well son, you must give me some assisance, for I have not dealt with the • amily before.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Will you have the horns put on first?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh, fye, fye! the last thing. Horns are aukward things, and many wear them, that would rather not. I have long suspected that I felt them growing. I will wear the breeches first.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: You need not try them on now, I do not doubt they will fit you very well, there are strings behind, that will let out the dress. Remember, tomorrow night, ready equiped, to meet me here at twelve. (exit Henry and Walter.)

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I will not fa • l. By our holy order this is not exactly right—if I am found out in this intrigue, 'twill be a ruinous stroke. (exit▪ )

div.stage: Enter DON PEDRAS, on the oposite side who picks up the letter.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: 'Tis well! your plans, shall now be stoped after this night you breathe no more. [exit.]

div.head: SCENE III.—Sea shore.—LORENZO discovered sleeping on a rock—Moon and star light—The horizon becomes obscured by degrees with heavy clouds. Thunder and lightning, then a heavy crash—The sea is envelloped in flames—after which FLORELLA rises from the ocean. Music.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sleep on Lorenzo, though I come for thee! I am Florella—I am she who to save me from thy sinful lust committed my body to the ocean. My immortal parts are now in heaven, where thou canst never come! Farewell, remember that I came for thee. (Angels decend from above, Florella ascends attended by them, invisible spirits chaunt.)

div.head: SCENE IV—A room in FLAVIO's House.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: 'Tis strange; Lorenzo is no where to be found'—This letter may be of most essential service to us both, I have explored the garden every part of it, not a room in the house, have I left unsearch'd, yet nothing can I find of Lorenzo.—Ha! yes, one there yet remains, one in which I have not look'd, but I cannot expect to find him there. (Exit.)

div.head: SCENE V.—Another room in FAVIO's House.— LORENZO discovered lying on a couch.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What ho! Lorenzo!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: (starting from his couch wildly.) Wait but a moment, I am not yet prepared!— (his face is covered with a deadly paleness, the sweat appears dropping from his face.)

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: For heaven's sake what alarms you thus?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Is it possible! or is it not?— (looks on Pedras with a frantic stare.)

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Are we on earth, or in the infernal regions? who are you?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Pedras.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My eyes yet are dim! like hail, the cold sweat in large drops roll down my icy cheeks!—Art thou indeed my friend;

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You have ever esteem'd me such.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How can I repay thee!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Snatching me from purgatory! where are we now?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Under your father's roof.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Is it possible? give me thy hand! give me
ocular demonstration! let me feel some flesh that's mortal beside my own. ( 〈◊〉
Pedras reaches him his hand.) 'Tis really so! I am more easy now, the convulsive spasms have almost let me. Oh! (sinks in Pedras's arms.)

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Heavens! what can be the cause of this? awake; Lorenzo!—rouse thee from this torpid state.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: (recovers slowly.) —Oh! I am very faint— my slow return of pulse, summons to their native spring my scatter'd senses!—surely this is not the place where but this moment legions of fiends were torturing my soul!—and at last 'twas but a dream!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But a dream.

sp.speaker: Lor,
sp.p: Aye Pedras 'twas nothing but a mere dream! —But oh! a dream so fraught with terror, ne'er visited the human frame before! 'tis almost impossible to tell! description would but mock reality. 'Twas naught but a flight of ideal fancy that quicken'd repose, and fasten'd the rocks of hell upon me, which I now have scarce shook off!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Think no more of it. I pray you be calm.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Command the raging tornado be calm. Bid the dread thunder of immortal Jove to cease threatning destruction, and the roaring winds to blow no more! thou wilt be as soon obey'd!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Of what did you dream?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Methought I lay upon a towering rock, whose fathom base lodg'd in the sea—The silver moon unclouded, and the twinkling stars, look'd more than common brilliant—when lo at distance a dark cloud with imperious frown advanc'd, and veil'd the heavens; the troubled ocean beat, and foam'd against the rock on which I lay—when looking down into the wat'ry steep I beheld Florella; she spoke to me a dreadful summons. Then Angels from Heaven descended, in whose arms her fleeting soul, majestically was born—
celestial strains accompanied her to the realms of immortal bliss!—She disappear'd, the dashing waters still'd, they turn'd to blood! and dire contention rose among the billows—Blood turn'd • o flames, and all was hell around me!—She cast her yelling evil spirits forth, who with menacing ghastly grins, seiz'd me trembling, convicted, and hurld'd me in the fiery gulph desponding! then in this vast abyss I lay, • tun'd by the violent shock; the tortures I endured, are not describable!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The more you think of this, the less happy you will be.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Oh that I had wak'd even then!—I was surrounded now on every side by those dread wretches, in each their left hands was held a flambeau, and in their right a forked spear; their jubilee at my being one of them, they signified by gesticulation most horrid, and wildly dancing round me!—of a sudden all this ghastly band stood still, their eyes beam'd terror and dismay, and from out their mouths they delug'd fire and smoke; I was seiz'd, and drag'd from out this everlasting fire and plac'd on a river's bank below— the waters up and down—far as my eyes could reach, on either side, were lin'd by those that brought me thither—on me all their basilisk eyes were rivetted— I saw on the opposite side a boat coming towards me, soon as it arriv'd, one voice alone, aloud exclaim'd—for all on the instant spoke, "Follow us, and mingle with the dam'd!"—but with so terrible, and vaunting peals, my ears for some long time fancied the sound of roaring thunder!—almost petrified I stood—they forc'd me in—they then put off—and when we gain'd the centre of the stygian flood, the tumultuous discord of those yelling fiends were horrible! those who lin'd the river far and near now instant all assembled round, menacing, with
their flambeaus destruction, and belching flames! as though each with the mineral combustion of mount Ae • na, or mount Vesuvius were pregnant; the boat then sunk in a flame of fire, and I awoke from out that sleeping torture, the effect of which though I were to live for ages, would never be from memory eras'd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This indeed is most wonderful!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O God! when will I have rest?—What shall I do to shake this terror off, that weighs so heavy on my soul? when e'er I lay me down to rest— 'stead of repose; my couch is contaminated—'tis the rendezvous of friends, who wake me frantic from my slumbers.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No more of this; think of your Isabella. I have been in search of thee, but being ta'en so long a time, attentively to hear this ill vision, I had forgot a letter I have found, directed to your rival, which he, I suppose by accident has lost. From your Isabella.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My Isabella! what does it contain of moment?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: To-morrow night—twelve o'clock is the hour appointed—a Friar, with Henry by the back way, thro' the garden ascends into her chamber, and he is there to make them one. No doubt his friend goes with him.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: We will counteract their project! we must be there before them. That name was music to my ears. (reviving.) But I cannot shake entirely off this dream of futurity—still it clings its iron gripe around m • , and hugs me to my fate. Henry must die; so must his friend Walter, no other way is left.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Thus, by one fatal blow, we'll end at once those two destroyers of our peace.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
In truth my spirits are quite low, strength do not desert me now, hold up my frame a little longer.
Don Pedras we will consult, and advise the most speedy, and surest method of revenge, But the sins I have already accumulated on my head, dulls the edge of my resolution, that I cannot sheath my enmity in the heart of my rival. (exit.)

div.head: SCENE VI.—A room in FLAVIO's House.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: I cannot think where I have lost the letter. But never mind, so it does not fall into the hands of my rival, I have nothing to fear. Are you still succesful with Florinda?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: She has promised to go with me at a moments warning, wherever my will directs. Flavio intends inclosing her in a nunnery to-morrow, should you not succeed this night, they both will be placed in bondage together.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Reflection will but mar our hopes—so, soon as possible we will be ready—take our Servants, and doubly arm ourselves. I like not the looks of Lorenzo, nor his friend Don Pedras, tho' they have profer'd so much kindness; there is a certain something still lurks behind their faces that warns me to be wary, Lorenzo's jealousy of me, and love for Isabella, if the letter should fall into his hands, wou'd enrage him to that degree, our lives might be in danger.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: We will defy them, unless, assassin like, they sink beneath the brute creation; though that they've done already.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Our time is short, we must depart immediately.

lg.l: Come let us prepare, the minute's nigh,
With LOVE and LIBERTY away we'll fly,

div.head: SCENE VII.—Time night.—CELIO's garden, the rear of his house is discovered, in the back ground.— A well decayed and old stands under ISABELLA's window.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What hour now?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: 'Tis near the time.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Our hiding places we must now seek out, or we may be discovered. Withdraw behind that arbour —I'll watch their coming. (Pedras withdraws.) — Let me not reflect on what I have done, nor what I am about to do—once done I'll think no more—but how can I forget? when the crimes I have committed, freezes every nerve. Murder! Oh, to that sound am I inur'd, though never hear it but my soul recoils! —Ha! they come! the long wish'd for hour is come, when to my hated rival I will guide the glittering steel, or leaden death quite home to his heart. (Exit behind the same arbour with Don Pedras.)

div.stage: Enter WALTER, HENRY, and SERVANTS, afterwards the FRIAR in a Devil's habit

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: The clock has struck, and no appearance of my charmer at her window yet.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: (To Servants.) Withdraw, should any alarm be given, immediately come to this spot; to our relief. (exit Servants.)

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Now time and opportunity serve. (Isabella appears at the window.)
Hist—Henry is it you?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: 'Tis the herald of immortal bliss·
O heavenly sound—'tis my Henry speaks.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: If thou will't call him so, for that sweet • ound to me is still more pleasing than an angels • hisper.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Where is the Friar?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: He is at hand, to make us happy.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Think you not your steps are traced? that villain Lorenzo, much I fear from him.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Be • ot alarmed my love, this dear moment is most precious, let us lose no time.
(sighs.) Oh Henry!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Why that sigh, so deep?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Aye deep indeed—it searched the inmost recess of my heart, something that is ill divining, throb'd at my breast—oh much I fear for you.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: If it be like mine, 'tis the voice of love that wakens with the peal.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: It may be so. To reach the window safely, here have I a ladder, made of ropes. (lowers the ladder out of the window.)

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Be no • alarmed my love. A Friar, masqued in the devils habit, I have brought with me; fearing our in • ent might be discover'd. I have brought with me my friend Walter likewise, with our servants.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Come then be speedy. I thought I heard a noise.

sp.speaker: Hen,
sp.p: Friar, mount you first.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: After you is manners. I never did such a thing in my life,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Throw then, ceremony aside, and obey me.

sp.speaker: Fri
sp.p: Well here I go, neck or nothing. (Climbs the ladder.— • wo pistols are fired, by Lorenzo and Don Pedras at them without effect. The Friar frighted at the r • p • rt, falls into the well—Servants rush on the stage—Lorenzo and Pedras fly—Henry, Walter and Servants pursue them—Music.)

div.head: ACT V.
SCENE I.—A Wine cellar in CELIO's House. Several pipes and quarter casks standing—Bottles, demijons, &c.
div.stage: SERVANTS drinking and carousing, nearly drunk.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: This is a happy country—he must be a fool who would not live in i • —what a pity it is we was'nt b • r • gentlemen, then we might be always drunk— and not fear the devil.

sp.speaker: 1st Ser
sp.p: No, • or the devil fear us—but I am always afraid of him.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: That's because you are a cowardly dog. But I care for no gentleman, no • I—getting a little tosticated, it makes a body feel so happy—ha! ha, he! he!—Come, some more of the excellent campaign for me.—Here is confusion to the moorish laws. (drinks.) Where is Lucett, my old piece?

sp.speaker: 1st. Serv.
sp.p: I never knew you to drink, but you always thought of women.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Drinking is somehow like the priming of a gun—but no more of that, it hurts my delicacy.

sp.speaker: 1st. Serv.
sp.p: Damn your delicacy say I.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And damn your impudence say I.

sp.speaker: 1st. Serv.
sp.p: I mean't no harm.

sp.speaker: 2nd. Serv.
sp.p: No, no—no harm was meant, we are all jovial fellows alike. I am as good a man as any b • dy
You are only a boy—feel your face.—To drown all amosity I'll give you a song.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Aye, aye, a song.

lg.l: Since jollification is the word,
And all hearts true that's here Sir;
We'll enter without fire or sword
Into what we've got here Sir,

lg.head: CHORUS.
lg.l: Come, come, my lads, then let us drink▪
We'll fill our glasses to the brink;
For Bacchus is a jolly soul,
The God of gods, so fill the bowl.
Of all the suction in the vault,
Give me good Champaign clear Sir;
I hate your liquor made of malt,
Oh! oh, damn your small bear Sir.
Come, come my lads, &c.
Since from our master we do steal,
While he's abed and sleeps sir,;
We'll drink his liquor 'till we feel,
Our eyes can hardly peep Sir.
Come, come my lads, &c.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Bravo, bravo!—

sp.speaker: 1st. Serv.
sp.p: He sings a good song.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: A go • d song may be badly sung:

div.stage: (During this scene, stones at different times fall into the cellar from the well which the FRIAR is in, who by this time has opened a place large enough—forces himself through—the Servants seem in great con • ternation, tumbling over each other drunk, and exit. FRIAR takes a bottle drinks, and exit. Music.

div.head: SCENE II.—Inside of a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh Florinda, snail-creeping time is tedious, our mutual destiny we will with patience bear; let sorrow drink quite dry her bitter cup▪ she her thirst may quench, that in after ages we may remain a great memento of constancy and love.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Must we then forever here remain, never more to scent the fragrant budding rose, or violets perfume; nor walter steal to these longing arms to heal my wounded heart? my spirits ebb apace, and soon will I fall a sacrifice, if not released from this drear solit • ry shrine—Oh! is there no ho • e?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I cannot cheer thee with one ray of hope— I cannot co • jure up one phantom favourable, that I shall behold my love, or thee thy Walter in this world again.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: When time with wrinkled front steals o'er the Parents head, with hoary locks most venerably 'thron'd—when vital spirits have forgot to flow, they of their former pleasures think no more, but doom with austere visage wrath eclips'd their darling tender progeny, to everlasting wretchedness and woe!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: (Sings without.) Florinda dear, oh listen, listen do.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Merciful heaven! 'twas my Walter's voice. Did'st thou not hear?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: [Sings without.] Isabella! dear, hear thy Henry too.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Oh blessed sound! how my heart beats? 'twas Henry's voice.

lg.head: AIR—WALTER, without.
lg.l: Thy Walter tho' thou'rt cag'd within these walls,
Immured by thy father's stern decree;
His love-rack'd soul, it so excessive galls,
He ne'er will rest 'till thou'rt at liberty.

lg.head: FLORINDA.
lg.l: My love is pure, as D • an's chaste,
No comfort in this world I'll know;
'Till I in Walter's arms am blest,
Then banish every thought of woe.

lg.head: HENRY, without.
lg.l: Isabella still thy Henry is true,
His ardent passion trust me burns the same,
The loss of thee indeed he'd sorely rue,
And death extinguish every vital flame.

lg.head: ISABELLA.
lg.l: Since thou art true as love can be,
And I unalter'd still remain;
Invention soon shall set me free,
To see my Idol once again

lg.head: Quarto—HEN. WAL. ISA. FLOR.
lg.l: Providence above, smiles on our love,
To that we'll trust our goodly cause;
We will fathers move, and to them prove,
If they infringe on nature's laws,
No power on earth will aid their cause.

div.head: SCENE III.—Outside of the Convent.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Can we contrive no plan, whereby we may succeed in liberating those lovely prisoners?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: There is none that we can think of, but set a woman's ingenuity to work, and if she does not succeed in any thing, no matter what it is, I would have a poor opinion of her.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Then you trust to their extricating themselv • s.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p:
No surer dependence rely on me—a woman's invention never fails, back'd with love's passion—no prison is strong enough—No balwark, tho' environ'd by barb • d steeds of chiva • ry, but the sex would sap; put two together, and the devil himself
would stand but a poor chance against them.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: You seem lively notwithstanding our ill success last night.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: That would be but trifling, had not Flavio and Celio put their daughters in this monkish tabernacle.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Have you a suspicion who those bravo's were, by whom we were attack'd last night • ?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: That villain Lorenzo, and his good friend Don Pedras, I'll be sworn. They must have found the letter you lost, which has betray'd us. We must pack up our baggage, and be off from the house, however.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Whither shall we go?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: To Pedrillo's in the next street, from thence after we have obtain'd the objects of our adoration, we'll fly from those shores to our native land America—where the bright sun each morn beams freedom, and independence.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: What has become of the unfortunate Friar?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I cannot tell. [looking off.] Ah! here he comes—how he has made his retreat good without a discovery is unaccountable.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: By his walk he appears much fatigued.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Welcome!—thrice welcome most honourable, most venerable, mostt ragicomic father.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh, what a world of sin is this! what miserable sinners are we all!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: With one exception father. Thou'rt not a sinner, tho' by thy garb, and outward 'meanour, thou art the father of all sin.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: If it be so—I think thou art the most devilish of all my children. O wicked abominable world. O such a night, such a night was never passed in purgatory,

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: You have then gone through your purgation Your sins are purg'd away.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: My fat is purg'd away you mean. Last night pull'd down my belly at such a rate, 'twill take a wonderful deal to fill it to its original size.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Where have you been all night?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: At the bottom of the sinful well—which is under that abominable window. Oh I have lost a deal of marrow fat. I am more hungry than a wolf—put a quill down my throat, and blow in it you would puff me up like a bladder—Oh! for a bottle of sack!

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: How did you contrive to sack that strongly fortified well?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I took it by storm.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: By storm!

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Truly son I took it by storm, for it did rain most terribly before I got out of it. Holy St. Francis only knows how long I was getting to the bottom, but I believe I was not very tedious.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: How did you escape from the well?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: By crawling out at the bottom.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—The top you mean.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p:
I am right; the bottom—there I lay stunn • ed by the violent fall—and then I began to dream— I dream'd I was in purgatory, and there I was like to stick, for I thought all poisonous hissing serpents were playing round about my face; and lo! when I awoke, these serpents were nothing but frogs, "and by my veracity one taking me to be a Frenchman had actually got into my mouth, and I gave him a very hard bite before he found out his mistake"This sentence is not the author's, but introduced by the translator.—I attempted after coming a little to myself to clamber out at the top, which I had nearly reached when a
stone on which my whole weight bore, dislodg'd and down falls the stone, and myself to the bottom again. "I smash'd some of the French diable gentry below, for they did croak most shockingly."Introduc'd by the translator.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: You have not yet got out, but just where you left off before.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: But I am getting out as fast as my tongue will carry me. Most unmercifully • mitten, I attempted to rise again but had not strength. There lay I bruised and jam'd in this hole—I recomended my soul to the supreme, though in truth good son I began to grow uneasy—fearing he would not hear me. I beheld a light thro' the hollow crevices of the stone wall, which I looked upon as a warning to prepare for the other country—I thought where my soul would go! dying with so heavy a sin upon my head—I heard some persons begin to sing, when I found there was nothing but the wall between me, and Celio's wine cellar, where his Servants were carousing—I set to work with fresh spirits—I tumbled out the sto • es, till I had made a hole large enough for myself to creep thro'—the Servants seeing, as they thought, the devil, crawling out of this ancient well, took to their drunken heels, and ran tumbling over each other frighten'd as bad as—

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: You at the report of the pistols, last night.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I believe so indeed—hem!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Here is that will lighten your heart, and weigh down your pocket. (gives purse.)

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p:
Thank you son. Come to my cell, and I'll give you absolution, gratis. But I have not finished yet, my unfortunate story. Having got clear from the house undiscovered, two great dogs standing in the street, fell foul of me—thanks to the rotten dress
that saved my flesh—I tore one of the horns from off my head, and p • y'd about them lustily—they was glad e • ough to quit—every one that see me • tar'd. The women squall'd! among them I know not what mischief I may have done, but my intentions were pure.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: We have no doubt of the purity of your intentions, among the women, father.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Wisely said indeed son. Farewell! If I can do any thing more in your way, I am your humble Servant. [exit Friar.]

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: [to Friar.] Remember, and send home the dress. We will now to Flavio's, take a round in his garden, bid him farewell, and leave his house. (exeunt)

div.head: SCENE IV.—Night. FLAVIO's Garden.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: The moon upon her other throne, darting pale illumine o'er the frowning night! the winds gently disordering the verd • nt leaves, from which the sweet scented air waf • s, seems to refresh my drooping melanc • olly. Isabella much I fear to me is lost forever. W • re my rival dead, some hope • otwithstanding I am so stongly repuls'd, might yet remain. Destiny bears his shield now o'er his head—but poison or daggers must, and shall, soon terminate his life! tho' my ill fa • ed stars thwart me in every attempt, h • must at last fall a victim to my artifice.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Signior, well met.
Why this haste?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
I bring thee news. Our rivals I have overheard. They suspect most s • rongly you, and likewise me, being the persons by whom they were assailed, last night—they intend leaving the house,
now is our only chance—this evening when they walk (which every night they do) into this garden, we will unawares, unseen, spring on them both, and we will rid at o • ce the world • f those lo • th some weeds, then we will stand u • rivalled.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well council'd Don Pedras—'tis near the time they walk. This, it cannot fail. But I am too credulous—I have before been as sure, and have been defeated.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Think of nothing now, but success.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: This is the main walk—station yourself and wait their coming on the left. Here on the opposite side shall be my po • t—on their appro • ch plunge home your stilletto to the hilt. I hear some noise, quick to your post. [Pedras conceals himself behind the left arbour, Lorenzo the right.]

div.stage: Enter from the top, WALTER and HENRY. Lorenzo and Pedras, spring at the same instant, and pass at their different rivals.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Assassins! thank heaven my coat is more my friend than thou. [draws and fights with Lorenzo. Walter fights with Don Pedras, who w • unded mortally • a • ls. Then runs to the assi • tance of H •• ry. Lorenzo, wounded in the head, saves himself by flight. Music.]

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I have made sure of Don Pedras. Exercise is good for the health.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: My sword pierced Lorenzo's head; he stagger'd and made his escape. I cannot but lament your c • ming to my aid, as I think he would not have fled but being c • mpelled by superior strength.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: I run Don Pedras through the gu • s, and I thought you might be in danger from Lorenzo. An assassin should be shewn no mercy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: Lorenzo will • ccuse us of something criminal! I dread the consequence.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: We must away imediately—each moment longer that we stay is fraught with danger. (exeunt.)

div.stage: LORENZO, with his head bound up in a handkerchief, enters cautiously, after some time looking round speaks.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: They're gone, and left Don Pedras weltering in his blood—surely they know me not. To good account my night's work is turn'd at last, tho' not in faith the way I wish'd it. Mayhap he is not yet quite dead, 'twill be a friendly office then to help him. What ho • ! Don Pedras!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: (recovers slowly▪ his vissage pale through loss of blood.) Oh thou prophetic seer! (wildly.)

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Art thou then alive my friend?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Is it Lorenzo's voice?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Help me! help me quick away, or we shall be discover'd! the alarm in the house, e'er this is given; quick, quick, for I am faint, very faint, through loss of blood.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Thy death is certain. Thy wound is very deep.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Not mortal, do assist me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: While you live I will; but thou hast not one minute of life.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I hope death is not so near.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: (aside.) If he lives, 'twill dicover my guilt. If he dies, to the world once more I am innocent in their eyes▪—Never before did the pangs which now I feel make such impression on me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Thanks Lorenzo, thanks—Thy strength but not thy simpathy can remove me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Look up thou matyr'd friend; friendship now must undergo a wondrous test; death now is only left to ea • e thy miseries—Impulse to relieve the
suff • rings of my friend, to cut short the thread of life already str • nded, labouring with conscience guilty and a mortal wound, forces me to this extremety. (stabs him.)

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Hold, hold, have mercy! Oh God forgive my sins as I forgive my murderer! (dies.)

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Death now has grappled with thee close, and safety's reassumed his marred throne, where guilt reigns umpire. Did I murder him? No, he was already kill'd, and I but d • m'd him before his time.— Shuddering conscience at such horrid perpetrations recoil, but I am so inur'd now to scenes of horror, methinks I could face unmov'd the grim visag'd fronts of cockatrice ey'd fiends, legions on legions. (seems for some time lost in thought.) I must remain no longer here, but to a Surgeon; then contrive means to unload suspicion's weight.— (Exit.)

div.head: SCENE V.—A room in CELIO's house.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Our daughters are safe enough, the two Americans to morrow leave us.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Where • o go?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: To an inn, in the next street.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Can you guess the cause?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: The cause is obvious enough; no hopes has Walter of Florinda, he can never extricate her from her prison, and Henry shares the fate of his friend. Gratitude got them in my favour, I will bestow every thing but my daughter, she must be married to Don Pedras.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p:
And thy virtuous son to my daughter;— when our children have been in the Nunnery less than a week, with downcast eyes and virgin blushing cheeks, they each will say, I'll marry whom you please. Then will my old heart dance, and thine
my brother will be transported too, we will feel young again, seeing our children happy, once married, love comes of course.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Then will hours fly swiftly o'er our heads, as minutes did before; the two Americans will reconcile themselves, and all will be happily settled.
(without.) Oh Sir, Sir, Sir—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: What noise was that?
What is the matter Fool?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Your daughters both are happy as kings!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I mean nothing but what I have said.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: But what have you said?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I have said enough, if you knew all. I'll tell you, but I'm sure you will not have patience to hear so unreli • hious a story.

sp.speaker: Cel·
sp.p: Speak to the purpose, or I'll knock you thro' the wall.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Then there would be an end of the story.— The short and longn • ss of the whole is this—Florinda and Isabella, both have flown away,

sp.speaker: Flav. and Cel.
sp.p: What escap'd?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yes, and for consolation I tell you they are marricated by this time.

sp.speaker: Cel. and Flav.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: That they will tell you.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Oh cursed hour!

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I'll tell you how all may yet be mamicably settled.

sp.speaker: Flav. and Cel.
sp.p: (earnestly.) Say how?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Leave 'em to themselves, and they'll depent of their folly.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: If my daugter is really married, then farewell comfort in this life forever,

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I guess they are comfortable enough, by this time.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Answer me, how made they their escape?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: You'll laugh when you hear it, tho' now you look so plaguy grum. Ha, ha, ha, who would a thought it—the two fat Monks fast asleep in the two ladies beds.

sp.speaker: Cel. and Flav.
sp.p: What the Monks in bed with my daughter?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: You put the worst destruction upon things; the two Monks are fast and tight asleep snoring like hogs in a mudgutter.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Did you see our daughters in bed with them?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: They didn't let me see that, ha, ha, ha, the snoring codgers, I believe will sleep 'till after they are dead, if they don't mind what they are about; they got asleep the sweetest way in the world—eating sweetmeats, and now they look as sour as vinegar.— The Friars was striped as naked, as if they had just come into the world, and put to bed by your daughters, who made their escape with the Friar's scowls on, I think you call um—and the Abbess took 'em to be the two Monks that now are snorting in bed▪

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Celio let's pursue them.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: They will stay till you come. I pinched 'em, and kicked 'em, but I could not wake um from their snortification. The Abbess guess'd the ladies put lodrum in their sweetmeats, makes um snort so.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I must learn the truth of this fool's story— If it is so, by heaven, I'll spurn her in the street, she dare approach me. (exit with Flavio.)

p.stage: (takes out a pot of sweatmeats from his pocket and eats.)

lg.head: SONG
lg.l: Since eating of sweetmeats they say,
Makes Friars to snort and to snore Sir,
From the Monks I stole this to day,
As back fast asleep they did stare, Sir.
Now here will I stuff my guts▪ oh,
Now my ma • ter is gone away, Sir,
'Tis better nor hickory nuts oh!
Or driving six horses and shay • ir,
Now here's to the Monks asleep oh!
May they groan and grunt 'till they die, Sir,
It would never make me weep, oh;
Though they'd make a fricasee fry Sir.

div.head: SCENE VI and Last.—A room in CELIO's House.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Alas! • o news of our disobedient children. Foolish girls—happy had I been to have seen my daughter a corpse, and • o stand on the brink of eternity myself, rather than have had my house dishonour'd.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Sir, sir, there be sir, a man by the do • r.— I ax'dum what he wanted, and he said nothing, I told him he shou • d have it, for he wanted to see you a bit.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: What appearance?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: He looks for all the world like, I do'nt know what.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Conduct him in. (exit Fool.)

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Perhaps some news of our run away children.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: I come, Signior Celio and Signior Flavio, from your daughters.
Where are they. Are they both married?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: They are.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Oh, cursed disobedience! Oh. (weeps)

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Oh, my lost child! (weeps)

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: As friend and confid • nte of the two fond pair, I here stand before you—they are about to depart.

sp.speaker: Flav. and Cel.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: To America.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Tell Florinda to depart, I ne'er will own her again.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: And tell Isabella likewise, for me; a fathers malediction shall pursue her through the wo • ld.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Think F • a • i • —Celio, think if you abandon your children; if you deny natures b • unty, a parent's blessing, the omnipotent ru •• r of the universe would double his malediction on that fathers head who unmoved, would hear a l • vely suppliant child, sue to him for pard • n.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Don Pedras lays in the g • rden, dead.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: What new accident is? this

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: As Don Pedras, and myself, in the garden were taking our usu • l walk, we heard a din of weapons, we ran to the spo • , and beheld the two Americans fighting resolutely against midnight bravoes, on whom we instan • ly ru • hed—Don Pedras receiv'd two mortal wounds and f • ll—we three then remained to co • b • t the ass • ssins, who fled. D • n Pedras in my arms expired, and his dying breath blessed thee and Florinda.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Why is thy head bound up.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A slight wound I received in rescuing my friends.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Your sis • er's married.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: And mine too Lorenzo, who was to have been thy wife.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: (wildly.) Ha, married! hadst thou laboriously studied f • r myriad • of years to end my life, thou needst but sum up all in two emphatic words, Isabella's married! to send me to perdition. (exit Lorenzo)

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: (to Servant.) F • llow and stop him should he at empt his own life. (exit Servant.) Don Pedras is dead. I forgive Florinda, (to Gent.) tell her to return to me with her husband, and I will grant my blessing to them both.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Tell Isabella from me the same. (exit gent.)

div.stage: Enter SERVANT shewing in WALTER, FLORINDA, HENRY and ISABELLA· Each kneel to their respective Parents. FLAVIO and CELIO raises them, and unites their hands.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: (to Walter and Florinda.) Heaven bless you as I do.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: I f • rgive you. (to H • nry and Isabella.)

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: But why is thy blessing so coolly bestow'd?

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: The severe wound my son received in his head last night, in those gentlemen's defence, in which conflict Don Pedras was kill'd makes me feel uneasy.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: (aside to Henry.) Since we are not accus'd we will not tell Lorenzo's perfidy. 'Twould break Flavio's and Florinda's heart to hear the truth.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
I followed Signior Lorenzo, he took from out his pocket a phial, which contained as I sup ••••
▪ some mortal dregs, he swallow'd them before I 〈◊〉 prevent him. [Flavio sinks into the arms of Celio, who bears him to a sopha.]

div.stage:
Enter LORENZO with countenance pale, eyes bloated, his • air di • hev • ll • d hanging on his shoulders the wound in his head bleeding—he goes to Fl • vio, kneels before him, takes his hand, puts it to his lips and kisses
it—Flavio recovers, and throws himself on his son's neck in speechless agony. Music.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Farewell! for dread eternity and me are linked together. One short minute and I am no more!

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Oh my son, in my mind already dead!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Didst thou know my unworthiness of life thou wouldst not regret the los • of me▪ (appears at intervals convulsed.) The mortal draught will let me tell no more.

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: Why w • rt thou so rash?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
A enging heaven demanded, I have obeye'd. Were 〈◊〉 my sins absol • ed, I'd die i • peace— (
• u • ns to Walter and H • nry.) 'Tis meet th • t I should die with all my sins upon my head, but even then I could not suffer the pangs, that I have immerged on my fellow creatures. I have no face to ask forgiveness, th • ' I have h • d the heart to p • rpetrate deeds too horrid ever to be named again.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.p: You have my pardon.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: And likewise mine.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: [Looks doubtingly on Isabella.] You have no cause to pity me, my heart has bee • c • ld and invincible to the voice of nature and of virtue—hard as the adamantine rock—I have been penitent, the next moment have sin'd again! were I new b • rn and innocent, I feel that now wi • hin me, tha • nothing could tempt me ever again to s • ray in the end • ess paths of vice.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: I do pity and forgive you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Tho' thou art all goodness, all purity, and matchless innocence, 'tis more than I could have hoped, much more indeed than I deserve. My soul i • much lighter by thy pard • ns, wherein my sins were center'd mos • ly. (more convulsed.) H • ! what sudden bolt was that shot before my eye • , like a meteor's long fiery trail? and now it leaves a pulse behi • d! Oh! the poison with impetuous power rushes thro'
every vein, each sinew artery!—my tongue cleaves to it's clammy roof!—And now the ague's rack begins to • hake my joints—the rolling ice, from off my forehead drops, and chattering teeth, are prelud • s to usher in the shaft of death!—my heart feels big within me, 'tis ready to burst!—It must have ven • —Oh! for a co • ling draught to quench my burning tongue!—my eyes grow big, and all around seems like a crim • on cloud about me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Heaven have mercy on my distracted brother.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Call not on heaven for mercy!—I have too little deserv'd it—Hark! what noise was that I heard as though some sepu • chre, had op'd its yawning vault, grating the rusty hinges, leaving wide the en • rance to mortality?—Hark! the tempest in my brain increases, does none hear the roar but me? the clamorous discord!—

sp.speaker: Flav.
sp.p: My heart is breaking.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: The strings of mine are already stretched be • ond their natural compass!—Florella has the jesses in her hand, and gives them to the tormenting fiends below!—The gnashing Spectres, hark how they yell and ghastly men • cing they now begin to pull. My heart is rent in twain!— (Dies.)
